title: Bill honoring Phoenix Horizon teen killed in semi crash gains support - AZCentral.com
text:
Bill honoring Phoenix Horizon teen killed in semi crash gains support Kaila White , The Republic | azcentral.com 4:51 p.m. MT Jan. 26, 2017 CLOSE x Share Tana Smith, the mom of Joe Smith, the teen who was killed in a semi crash last summer, testifies in support of Senate Bill 1054 a.k.a. "Joe's Law" at a State Senate committee meeting Jan. 26, 2017, at the Arizona State Capitol in Phoenix. Mark Henle/azcentral.com Supporters hold signs on Jan. 26, 2017, at the Arizona Capitol in Phoenix, before a hearing on a bill in honor of Joe Smith, a Phoenix teen killed in a semi crash. Supporters include Gabrielle Bell (second from right), who was Joe's girlfriend. (Photo: Mark Henle/The Republic) 
A bill in honor of Joe Smith, a recent Phoenix Horizon High School graduate who was killed in a horrific crash on Interstate 10 in June, is one step closer to becoming law. 
A state Senate committee unanimously voted Thursday in support of Senate Bill 1054, also known as "Joe's Law," which would make it mandatory for law enforcement to give drug and alcohol testing to anyone who caused a traffic accident resulting in death or serious injury. 
As it stands, Arizona law says officers may require drivers to submit to blood-alcohol testing or drug testing. Individual police agencies, however, can set their own policies. 
"It’s nothing anybody thinks about because they think it’s already required, but when you lose your son, you think about it," Joe's father, Steve Smith, said while standing outside the Arizona Capitol on Thursday morning, where about 100 people gathered to show support. x Share Steve and Tana Smith talk about the death of their son Joe and the subsequent investigation that led to no charges being filed against he driver of the semitruck that struck the car in which Joe was a passanger. David Kadlubowski/azcentral.com 
Friends held up signs bearing Joe's senior portrait outside the Senate building, while about 20 people went inside to see Joe's mother, Tana, testify in the bill's first hearing. 
"It is our greatest hope that the legislation before you will be the help so many grieving families need as they, too, search for answers from disasters similar to ours," she told the state Senate's Judiciary Committee. Returning home from a graduation trip 
Joe Smith (second from left) and friends on their graduation trip to California. Joe was killed in a crash on Interstate 10 in June on the way back from this trip. (Photo: Special for The Republic) 
Joe and three of his best friends were returning June 17 from a graduation trip to California when, while stopped on Interstate 10 near Quartzsite for heavy traffic, a semi driver plowed into them and another car, killing two and severely injuring four . 
The 42-year-old semi driver said he was tired and appeared to be so, records show, and troopers did not test him for drugs or alcohol. 
"It is the not knowing that is the hardest part to accept," Tana Smith told the committee before presenting a stack of petitions she said had 3,191 signatures in favor of the bill . 
Her account brought Sen. Lupe Contreras to tears. Contreras, D-District 19, was in an accident as a kid that killed his 18-year-old sister and said he knows the pain a family endures. 
"It’s so important to have healing in a family, and I think this is one way that we, as a state, can move forward and help families come together and feel that justice is there for them," said Sen. Judy Burges, R-District 22, who chairs the committee and is the prime sponsor of the bill. 
The committee voted unanimously to recommend that the bill move on. The bill still needs a full Senate vote before going to the House of Representatives. 'We needed this' 
Gabrielle Bell, Joe Smith's girlfriend; Steve Smith, his father; and Jamie Smith, his sister, hug after a hearing on Senate Bill 1054 on Jan. 26, 2017, at the Arizona Capitol in Phoenix. (Photo: Mark Henle/The Republic) 
People cried and hugged as they left the hearing, and dozens cheered in celebration for Tana, Steve and their 11-year-old daughter, Jamie. 
"Even though it’s not helping our current situation, it will help another family from ever having to wonder," said Gabrielle Bell, who was Joe's girlfriend. 
"The amount of support, that’s what helped the most," she said. "It’s been seven months now, and it’s getting better but, I mean, I miss him every day. There’s not a moment I don’t think about him. 
"If we could help another family from ever having to go through that, that’s healing for us. That’s all we can ask for. We needed this. We need this."
